channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Free Lunch? Yes, Please. Perl job in Vienna.
item.description: One of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries is on the hunt for a Perl programmer who wants to use their skills to eradicate inflated prices. The successful candidate will relish the chance to join a team that attributes nearly two decades of success to an uncompromising commitment to transparency, objectivity, and quality content.

item.title: Just Another Day Working in Perl Paradise (Perl developer job in Malta)
item.description: Surrounded by the dazzling turquoise waters of the Mediterranean Sea, Malta is known for its 300 days of sunshine, its comprehensive and incredibly inexpensive healthcare, its arts and culture, and the delectable cuisine. English is an official language, and all government documents are offered in English, so the transition to life in Malta is easy-as-pie.

item.title: Why let Silicon Valley have all the Fun? Perl Developer job in Cyberjaya / Kuala Lumpur
item.description: Our client is a financial company whose growth over the last twenty years has been nothing short of impressive. They started with the idea that online trading should be available to all, and from there, they’ve built a company with multiple locations worldwide. If you want to be part of a business that is thriving, this may be the perfect opportunity for you.

item.title: Adventure Awaits for one Lucky Perl Developer in Dubai
item.description: Our client's Dubai office is looking for Perl developers with a strong exposure to Modern Perl – you’ll be comfortable with Plack/PSGI, Moose, and writing tests. Ready to trade your 9-to-5 for an exciting new role in sunny Dubai? Then pack your skis, your swimsuit, and start the application process!

item.title: The Perl Foundation, the Perl Weekly, and marketing
item.description: Should the Perl Weekly be folded into perl.org?

item.title: LinkedIn Hashtags and follower counts
item.description: If I am already investing a lot of time and energy posting on LinkedIn, I would like to have a bigger impact and reach more people. One way to do that is to use hashtags. So I was really curious how many people follow various hashtags that might be relevant to the subjects I write about.

item.title: LinkedIn Pages - by language or by topic?
item.description: I have now 8 LinkedIn pages. I think I got a bit carried away. The question, shall I group my posts by human language or by topic? Or maybe both?

item.title: Perl Maven LinkedIn page
item.description: If you have an account on LinkedIn, follow this new page where I am going to share code-snippets, examples, and quizzes about Perl. Help me reach others by like-ing the posts.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: How to contribute to an Open Source Perl project
Get absolute path (aka. canonical path) using abs_path or canonpath

item.description: Colin is one of few members of Team PWC whose blogging skill is exceptional. Highly Recommended.

item.description: Arne is kindly sharing his Perl side now. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Raku Challenge Week 68
item.description: Andrew continued his journey with the weekly challenge and shared another gem from his collections.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 068
item.description: Recap of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.description: This was fun reading, as it solved the encoding issue in one of Flavio script.

item.description: If you read the earlier blog about Bézier curves then you are going to find this interesting as well.

item.title: Bézier curves
item.description: What is Bézier curves? well read the short blog to find out more about it.

item.title: Type System for Cor
item.description: Curtis shared the proposal for the Type System for Cor.

item.title: Chicago.pm Virtual Meeting: July 23
item.description: David announced the virtual meeting of Chicago.pm.

item.title: #468 - Is Cor the solution?
item.description:
Hi there

If you ask me this question today, then my short answer would be "Yes". I give credit to every member of the team working on the project. Curtis being one of them who does all the talk. If you follow the usual public platform like Facebook, Twitter and blogs.perl.org then you would see the regular updates from him. It is always nice to that it is making steady progress. Above all, it is making positive noise. My personal opinion is that Cor has been accepted by the wider Perl community based on what I read so far by various high profile members of the Perl community.

There is another news that caught my eyes last week, was an honest attempt by TPF and the marketing team headed by Mark Keating to make Perl #1 again. We as a community need to help the team to achieve the target. I was approached by the team and I humbly accepted to be a part of it. As of now, I don't know how I am going to help the cause. Hopefully in the coming weeks, the marketing team would make the plan crystal clear.

On a side note, this is my 56th edition of the newsletter. With this, I have now gone past Neil Bowers (55 issues). The only editor who has done more than me is now Yanick Champoux (63 issues). It would take another 4 months to go past him and becomes the second in line after the chief editor Gabor Szabo (264 issues).

Last but not the least, you take care of yourself and your family. Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
